articles.headline: 2 Central Banks Promise to Keep Rates Low
articles.snippet: Neither the European Central Bank nor the Bank of England had made such a move before. The bid to reassure investors brought them into closer alignment with the Federal Reserve.
articles.abstract: Neither the European Central Bank nor the Bank of England had made such a move before. The bid to reassure investors brought them into closer alignment with the Federal Reserve.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Answering critics who said they were running out of ways to promote growth and lending, the European Central Bank and the Bank of England on Thursday did something neither had done before, committing themselves to keeping interest rates low indefinitely.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: In Ireland, Dire Echoes of a Bailout Gone Awry
articles.snippet: As American regulators aim for a harder line on big banks, a newspaper in Ireland says audiotapes prove that bankers were lying during the 2008 crisis.
articles.abstract: As American regulators aim for a harder line on big banks, a newspaper in Ireland says audiotapes prove that bankers were lying during the 2008 crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Irish bank bailout in the fall of 2008 was the first one to hit a euro zone country during the credit crisis, and it set some unfortunate precedents.

articles.headline: As Competition Wanes, Amazon Cuts Back Discounts
articles.snippet: After years of lowering book prices, Amazon is offering smaller discounts on some books. Authors and small publishers said this put some books beyond an audience’s reach.
articles.abstract: After years of lowering book prices, Amazon is offering smaller discounts on some books. Authors and small publishers said this put some books beyond an audience’s reach.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jim Hollock’s first book, a true-crime tale set in Pennsylvania, got strong reviews and decent sales when it appeared in 2011. Now “Born to Lose” is losing momentum — yet Amazon, to the writer’s intense frustration, has increased the price by nearly a third.

articles.headline: Warren Mosler, a Deficit Lover With a Following
articles.snippet: From his home in the Virgin Islands, Mr. Mosler is waging a well-financed academic battle against economists who want to cut government spending.
articles.abstract: From his home in the Virgin Islands, Mr. Mosler is waging a well-financed academic battle against economists who want to cut government spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHRISTIANSTED, V.I. — Warren Mosler is a card-carrying member of the 1 percent. A deeply tanned, tennis-lean hedge fund executive, Mr. Mosler lives on this run-down but jewel-toned Caribbean island for tax reasons. Transitioning into an active retirement, he recently designed and had built an $850,000 catamaran called Knot My Problem. He whizzes around St. Croix in a white, low-slung sports car he created himself, too.

articles.headline: Résumé Shows Snowden Honed Hacking Skills
articles.snippet: Edward J. Snowden’s résumé suggests that he transformed himself into the kind of cybersecurity expert the National Security Agency is desperate to recruit.
articles.abstract: Edward J. Snowden’s résumé suggests that he transformed himself into the kind of cybersecurity expert the National Security Agency is desperate to recruit.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2010, while working for a National Security Agency contractor, Edward J. Snowden learned to be a hacker.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Scott Shane

articles.headline: I.R.S. Scrutiny Went Beyond the Political
articles.snippet: A closer look at the I.R.S. operation suggests that the problem was less about ideology than about the indiscriminate application of a process instructing reviewers to “be on the lookout” for selected terms.
articles.abstract: A closer look at the I.R.S. operation suggests that the problem was less about ideology than about the indiscriminate application of a process instructing reviewers to “be on the lookout” for selected terms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2010, a tiny Palestinian-rights group called Minnesota Break the Bonds applied to the Internal Revenue Service for tax-exempt status. Two years and a lot of prodding later, the I.R.S. sent the group’s leaders a series of questions and requests almost identical to the ones it was sending to Tea Party groups at the time.

articles.headline: For Islamists, Dire Lessons on Politics and Power
articles.snippet: The overthrow of President Mohamed Morsi demonstrated for some the futility of democracy, but others faulted the leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood for reaching too fast for so many levers of power.
articles.abstract: The overthrow of President Mohamed Morsi demonstrated for some the futility of democracy, but others faulted the leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood for reaching too fast for so many levers of power.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Sheik Mohamed Abu Sidra had watched in exasperation for months as President Mohamed Morsi and the Egyptian Muslim Brotherhood bounced from one debilitating political battle to another.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Samsung Cuts Its Forecast as Sales Growth Slows for Its Costliest Smartphones
articles.snippet: The Korean electronics giant estimated quarterly profit of $8.3 billion, short of analysts’ expectations, as sales of Galaxy S4 smartphones slowed.
articles.abstract: The Korean electronics giant estimated quarterly profit of $8.3 billion, short of analysts’ expectations, as sales of Galaxy S4 smartphones slowed.
articles.lead_paragraph: Samsung Electronics may be having the same problem Apple has: nearly everyone in the world who can afford an expensive smartphone has one already.

articles.headline: Mayhem in Cairo as Morsi Backers Fight for Return
articles.snippet: At least 30 people have died in clashes between those celebrating the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi and those demanding his reinstatement.
articles.abstract: At least 30 people have died in clashes between those celebrating the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi and those demanding his reinstatement.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s bitter split over who should be ruling the country exploded into violent clashes in the streets of Cairo and elsewhere on Friday as masses of demonstrators celebrating the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi battled crowds of Islamists who wanted him reinstated.

articles.headline: Jobs Data Is Strong, but Not Too Strong, Easing Fed Fears
articles.snippet: The economy added 195,000 jobs in June, a pace sufficient to please investors but muted enough to calm worries of an abrupt end to the Federal Reserve’s bond-buying program.
articles.abstract: The economy added 195,000 jobs in June, a pace sufficient to please investors but muted enough to calm worries of an abrupt end to the Federal Reserve’s bond-buying program.

articles.headline: For the Employment Rate, an Uptick
articles.snippet: The share of American adults with jobs rose slightly in June, to 58.7 percent. That matches the highest level since the end of the recession, but remains well below the prevailing level before the recession.
articles.abstract: The share of American adults with jobs rose slightly in June, to 58.7 percent. That matches the highest level since the end of the recession, but remains well below the prevailing level before the recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: The share of American adults with jobs rose slightly in June, to 58.7 percent. That matches the highest level since the end of the recession in 2009, but remains well below the prevailing level before the recession.

articles.headline: A Surge in Part-Time Workers
articles.snippet: The June jobs report saw a surge in part-time workers, and the health care law that starts coming into full effect next year might be in part responsible.
articles.abstract: The June jobs report saw a surge in part-time workers, and the health care law that starts coming into full effect next year might be in part responsible.
articles.lead_paragraph: The June jobs report saw a surge in part-time workers, and the health care law that starts coming into full effect next year might be in part responsible. The number of part-time workers for economic reasons climbed to 8.2 million in June from 7.6 million in March.

articles.headline: Boss’s Remark, Employee’s Deed and Moral Quandary
articles.snippet: A federal complaint raises the question of whether Jon Corzine, chief executive of MF Global, should have known that an instruction to an employee would lead to illegal activity.
articles.abstract: A federal complaint raises the question of whether Jon Corzine, chief executive of MF Global, should have known that an instruction to an employee would lead to illegal activity.
articles.lead_paragraph: About 9 a.m. on Friday, Oct. 28, 2011, Jon Corzine, chief executive of MF Global and formerly a United States senator, governor of New Jersey and chief executive of Goldman Sachs, called Edith O’Brien, the assistant treasurer of MF Global in Chicago, according to a complaint filed last week by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
